entry.title: ABAP SALV Table with Checkbox Column, Select/Deselect All, and Email Export Functionality
entry.content:
Hi all,

I have developed an ABAP report that displays employee data in a SALV table with a checkbox column. Users can select/deselect rows using custom toolbar buttons, and send the selected data as an Excel attachment via email.

The SALV table includes clickable checkboxes that toggle selection, and I handle user commands for selecting all, deselecting all, and sending email.

Please review the code below. Any suggestions on improving performance, best practices, or adding additional features would be appreciated!

Thank you!
Tcode :SE41

Create a PF Status

REPORT zsalv_factory_disply_checkbox.

" Type definition for internal table representing employee data with a checkbox
TYPES: BEGIN OF t_zemployee,
         checkbox       TYPE c LENGTH 1,                " Checkbox for selection
         employee_id    TYPE zemploye-employee_id,     " Employee ID
         company_code   TYPE zemploye-company_code,    " Company code
         bankid         TYPE zemploye-bankid,          " Bank ID
         insurance_id   TYPE zemploye-insurance_id,    " Insurance ID
         empname        TYPE zemploye-empname,         " Employee Name
         remarks        TYPE zemploye-remarks,         " Remarks
         date_of_join   TYPE zemploye-date_of_join,     " Date of Joining
         date_of_resign TYPE zemploye-date_of_resign,  " Date of Resignation
         salary         TYPE zemploye-salary,           " Salary
         currency       TYPE zemploye-currency,         " Currency
         commission     TYPE zemploye-commission,       " Commission
         currency23     TYPE zemploye-currency23,       " Additional Currency
       END OF t_zemployee.

" Global internal tables to hold employee data and selected records
DATA: gt_data  TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF t_zemployee,
      seleted  TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF t_zemployee,
      gv_repid TYPE sy-repid VALUE sy-repid.

CLASS lcl_app DEFINITION.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CLASS-METHODS:
      get_data,                        " Fetch data from DB into internal table
      display_data,                    " Display SALV table with checkbox
      refresh_display,                 " Refresh the SALV table display
      send_email,                     " Send selected data as email attachment
      convert_itab_to_xls_xstring     " Convert internal table to XLS XSTRING
        RETURNING VALUE(rv_xstring) TYPE xstring,
      on_link_click FOR EVENT link_click OF cl_salv_events_table
        IMPORTING row column,         " Event handler for checkbox click
      handle_user_command FOR EVENT added_function OF cl_salv_events_table
        IMPORTING e_salv_function.    " Handler for custom toolbar functions

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    CLASS-DATA: gr_table TYPE REF TO cl_salv_table.   " Reference to SALV table object
ENDCLASS.

CLASS lcl_app IMPLEMENTATION.

  " Method to fetch employee data from database and initialize checkbox field
  METHOD get_data.
    IF gt_data IS INITIAL.
      SELECT * FROM zemploye INTO CORRESPONDING FIELDS OF TABLE gt_data.
      LOOP AT gt_data ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs>).
        <fs>-checkbox = ''.  " Initialize checkbox as empty (unchecked)
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDIF.
  ENDMETHOD.

  " Method to display the SALV table with checkbox and event handlers
  METHOD display_data.
    lcl_app=>get_data( ).  " Load data

    IF gr_table IS INITIAL.
      TRY.
          cl_salv_table=>factory(
            IMPORTING r_salv_table = gr_table
            CHANGING  t_table      = gt_data ).
        CATCH cx_salv_msg INTO DATA(lx).
          MESSAGE lx->get_text( ) TYPE 'E'.
          RETURN.
      ENDTRY.

      " Enable all standard functions in SALV toolbar
      gr_table->get_functions( )->set_all( ).

      TRY.
          " Set custom GUI status with custom functions (PF-STATUS 'ZTOOLBAR')
          gr_table->set_screen_status(
            EXPORTING
              report        = gv_repid
              pfstatus      = 'ZTOOLBAR'
              set_functions = gr_table->c_functions_all ).
        CATCH cx_salv_msg.
      ENDTRY.

      " Set checkbox column as hotspot to allow click events
      DATA lr_columns TYPE REF TO cl_salv_columns_table.
      DATA lr_column  TYPE REF TO cl_salv_column_table.
      lr_columns = gr_table->get_columns( ).
      lr_columns->set_optimize( abap_true ).

      TRY.
          lr_column ?= lr_columns->get_column( 'CHECKBOX' ).
          lr_column->set_cell_type( if_salv_c_cell_type=>checkbox_hotspot ).
          lr_column->set_short_text( 'Select' ).
        CATCH cx_salv_not_found.
      ENDTRY.

      " Register event handlers for checkbox clicks and user commands
      DATA lo_events TYPE REF TO cl_salv_events_table.
      lo_events = gr_table->get_event( ).
      SET HANDLER lcl_app=>on_link_click FOR lo_events.
      SET HANDLER lcl_app=>handle_user_command FOR lo_events.

    ELSE.
      " Refresh SALV table if already created
      gr_table->refresh( ).
    ENDIF.

    gr_table->display( ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  " Refresh display wrapper method
  METHOD refresh_display.
    lcl_app=>display_data( ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  " Event handler to toggle checkbox on clicking checkbox cell
  METHOD on_link_click.
    FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs> TYPE t_zemployee.
    READ TABLE gt_data ASSIGNING <fs> INDEX row.
    IF sy-subrc = 0.
      IF <fs>-checkbox = 'X'.
        <fs>-checkbox = ''.
      ELSE.
        <fs>-checkbox = 'X'.
      ENDIF.
    ENDIF.
    lcl_app=>refresh_display( ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  " Convert selected internal table data to XLS XSTRING format for attachment
  METHOD convert_itab_to_xls_xstring.
    TRY.
        cl_salv_table=>factory(
          EXPORTING
            list_display = abap_false
          IMPORTING
            r_salv_table = DATA(lo_salv_table)
          CHANGING
            t_table      = seleted ).
      CATCH cx_salv_msg INTO DATA(lx_mail).
        MESSAGE lx_mail TYPE 'E'.
    ENDTRY.

    rv_xstring = lo_salv_table->to_xml( xml_type = if_salv_bs_xml=>c_type_xlsx ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  " Send email with the selected employee data as an Excel attachment
  METHOD send_email.
    TRY.
        " Create persistent email object
        DATA(lo_mail) = cl_bcs=>create_persistent( ).

        " Sender email address
        DATA(lo_sender_address) = cl_cam_address_bcs=>create_internet_address(
                                    i_address_string = 'maniyadav2585@gmail.com' ).
        lo_mail->set_sender( lo_sender_address ).

        " Recipient email address
        DATA(recipient_address) = cl_cam_address_bcs=>create_internet_address(
                                    i_address_string = 'maniyadav2585@gmail.com' ).
        lo_mail->add_recipient( i_recipient = recipient_address ).

        " Create email document with subject and body text
        DATA(lo_document) = cl_document_bcs=>create_document(
                              i_type    = 'htm'
                              i_subject = `Excel Attachment`
                              i_text    = VALUE #( ( CONV #( 'Excel Attachment' ) ) )
                              i_sender  = lo_sender_address ).

        " Convert selected data to XLS format for attachment
        DATA(lv_excel_data) = convert_itab_to_xls_xstring( ).

        " Add the Excel attachment
        lo_document->add_attachment(
          i_attachment_type     = 'XLS'
          i_attachment_subject  = 'Employee Information'
          i_attachment_size     = xstrlen( lv_excel_data )
          i_att_content_hex     = cl_bcs_convert=>xstring_to_solix( lv_excel_data ) ).

        lo_mail->set_document( lo_document ).
        lo_mail->set_send_immediately( abap_true ).

        " Send the email
        DATA(lv_send_success) = lo_mail->send( ).
        COMMIT WORK.

      CATCH cx_send_req_bcs cx_address_bcs cx_document_bcs INTO DATA(lx_mail).
        MESSAGE lx_mail TYPE 'E'.
    ENDTRY.
  ENDMETHOD.

  " Handle custom toolbar commands (Select All, Deselect All, Send, Back)
  METHOD handle_user_command.
    FIELD-SYMBOLS: <fs> TYPE t_zemployee.
    DATA lv_count TYPE i VALUE 0.

    CASE e_salv_function.
      WHEN 'SELALL'.
        LOOP AT gt_data ASSIGNING <fs>.
          <fs>-checkbox = 'X'.
        ENDLOOP.
        lcl_app=>refresh_display( ).

      WHEN 'DESALL'.
        LOOP AT gt_data ASSIGNING <fs>.
          <fs>-checkbox = ''.
        ENDLOOP.
        lcl_app=>refresh_display( ).

      WHEN 'SEND'.
        " Collect selected records for sending
        LOOP AT gt_data ASSIGNING <fs> WHERE checkbox = 'X'.
          lv_count = lv_count + 1.
          APPEND <fs> TO seleted.
        ENDLOOP.

        IF lv_count = 0.
          MESSAGE 'Please select at least one record before sending.' TYPE 'E'.
          RETURN.
        ENDIF.

        lcl_app=>convert_itab_to_xls_xstring( ).
        lcl_app=>send_email( ).

        IF sy-subrc = 0.
          MESSAGE |{ lv_count } row(s) selected and sent.| TYPE 'S'.
        ENDIF.

      WHEN 'BACK'.
        LEAVE TO SCREEN 0.
    ENDCASE.
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

" Program starts here
START-OF-SELECTION.
  SET PF-STATUS 'ZTOOLBAR'.  " Set custom toolbar with your custom functions
  lcl_app=>display_data( ).

 

 

OutPut:

ABAP Connectivity

entry.title: AI Assisted Data Quality Screening in SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Ensuring Data Excellence in Mixed-Source Environments Through AI & Automated Frameworks

Introduction

Organizations today rely on data from multiple sources to drive critical business decisions in their data platform. SAP Business Data Cloud  excels at integrating both SAP and non-SAP data into a unified platform. However maintaining consistent data quality across these diverse sources presents unique challenges, especially for the non-SAP data.

SAP Business Applications typically deliver high-quality data thanks to their robust semantically rich business logic and built-in validation rules applied at the point of extraction. However, non-SAP data sources often lack these same quality safeguards, creating potential inconsistencies that can compromise analytical outcomes.

Poor data quality isn't just a technical inconvenience - it's a business risk that directly impacts your organization's ability to compete & make accurate decisions and trust the data. That’s why it should be top of mind in a data platform design to have a continuous solution.

 

What did we do?

SAP Datasphere  includes native data integrity checks, these require manual execution. But our purpose was to build something that could screen an entire environment daily & report back on the data quality inconsistencies. And we wanted it to have as little manual work to setup so we built it from the top up with AI in mind to assist

To bridge this gap, my colleagues and I have developed an advanced AI assisted Data Quality Framework (DQF) specifically engineered for SAP Datasphere environments. This framework transforms data quality management from a reactive, manual process into a proactive, automated system that continuously monitors, evaluates, and reports on data integrity across all sources.

It transforms data quality management from a time-consuming manual process into an automated system that works at the speed of your business, ensuring that every piece of data in your SAP Datasphere environment - regardless of its origin - meets the same rigorous standards you expect from native SAP business applications even when the data is not coming from SAP.

In this blog, we'll examine the key features, how this framework was built, its core capabilities, and how to use it and what results it brings. The goal is to showcase the near limitless possibilities within SAP Business Data Cloud as a modern data environment.

 

  • Key Features and Benefits

The Data Quality Framework (DQF) is meticulously designed to ensure the integrity and accuracy of data within SAP Datasphere, especially of non-SAP data & manual data like excel, csv, etc. The framework performs a series of critical checks, including the identification of NULL values in key fields, referential integrity checks with master data, and duplicate records detection. These checks provide accurate record-level details necessary for data validation, cleansing, governance, and monitoring and reporting.

At the end the results of the checks are posted to a report which can be used by IT or business to fix the data quality & integrity issues in the files or systems.

 

  • Use Cases and Prerequisites

The Data Quality Framework is versatile and can validate data from various sources, including non-SAP sources like Databases, CSV files, excel files, etc. It can also be used to do checks on data created within  SAP Datasphere after using joins.

The setup requires access to the SAP HANA Cloud Database in SAP Datasphere & setup of a user, couple of tables & Stored procedures in that HANA Layer. Additionally, any views the stored procedure needs to screen should be exposed for consumption.

 

  • Architecture

The architecture of our DQF is designed to handle screenings efficiently & automatically and showcase the errors to end users to take action on the Data Quality itself.

The process begins with the main procedure: the ETL_RunScreenings. This script starts the process with a couple of parameters to allow customisability: Only check object x, only check objects in space y, only execute check 1.

The orchestra master if you will is a list called Screenings. This is an AI generated table that consists all of the screening rules per data object in your data platform. See an example below. We gave an agent the structure of the table, the functional blueprint of the DQF, code & ERD schema’s of our Data Warehouse Billing Model. The question was then asked: Populate this table to the best of your ability. The result:

Following this, the Framework then branches into three critical checks: ETL_SCREEN_REFERENTIAL_INTEGRITY, ETL_SCREEN_DUPLICATE, and ETL_SCREEN_NULLKEYS. Each of these checks points to respective error tables, ensuring that any discrepancies are promptly identified and addressed. The framework allows for multiple ETL Screening but currently there are 3:

  • Referential Integrity check: Checks if the key value in a fact finds a key value in the dimension. This ensures an association will retrieve master data.
  • Duplicate Check: Checks if a duplicate exists on a certain key
  • Null Keys/mal keys Check: Checks if one of the fields that is set as key has null values

 

  • Implementation Steps

Implementing the DQF involves several key steps:

  1. Create a database user in the Datasphere tenant. (Use Space Management)
  2. Create tables and stored procedures in the open SQL schema of the created database user. (Code will shared later once quality reviewed – we used DBeaver for this)
  3. Grant access to the Datasphere space for the task chain to access the stored procedures.
  4. Create task chains to schedule the stored procedure runs.
  5. Feed an AI Agent or LLM of choice with the code, table layout of SCREENING & ERD schema of your model and ask to fill in the rules. Do a visual check afterward & manually adjust where needed.
  6. Create a view to combine the screening tables.
  7. Report errors using a report built in SAP Analytics Cloud 

 

  • End Result

To illustrate the practical application of the DQF, let’s look at example diagram of the data flow in a DSP system. The diagram highlights the flow of data from source entities through transformations and unions, leading to storage and further processing. Key elements include entities, dimensions, facts, attributes, and a screening framework, with specific keys and NULL replacements noted.

The result is an error page on which you can build a report. See example below where it shows what constraint was violated in what screening run & what the values were that caused the error. See for example line 7 where a duplicate key was found & then it shows the exact key that created the duplicate.

A business or IT user can then take matters into control & fix the data at source based on this report. Or coordinate if action/logic needs to be developed in the Data Platform to catch this.

 

Conclusion

In conclusion: the Data Quality Framework we created is an AI-driven automated solution to enhance data integrity and accuracy within SAP Datasphere & SAP Business Data Cloud on a constant basis. It builds on top of the already powerful manual integrity checks. But the framework expands by offering a daily, automated & AI assisted approach. By implementing these kind of checks consistently, organizations can ensure that their data is reliable, consistent, and ready for informed decision-making.

What’s next? We are looking to expand to do data type check. We are now also running full validation on the script & doing some code quality & clean-up. Once this is done, we can share the script. Feel free to contact me at simon.vandelanotte@delaware.pro if you want a sneak peak.

Because fun fact: The script was partly written thanks to assistance from AI. As neither Premalatha or myself are SQLscript coders from background, this was our first experience!

I hope this case already inspires on the endless possibilities with SAP Business Data Cloud& inspire around the important topic of Data Quality and how proactively being on top of this is critical to the success of a modern data platform. And lastly how AI doesn’t replace the process but can enhance it & save time.

Big thanks to my colleague Premalatha Kamaraj for writing this script & Gilles De Rore for the idea!

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Table Maintenance Reimagined: Choosing the Right Framework
entry.content:
In this blog, we’ll explore a practical use case implemented in S/4HANA 2021 On-Premise, where we opted for Custom Business Objects (CBO) to enable table maintenance via Fiori with minimal development effort and also evaluate new frameworks to achieve this in latest S4/HANA release 2023.

Approach for choosing Custom Business Object (Decision Matrix)

CBO is based on BOPF framework which was widely used by SAP before the era of RAP (RESTful ABAP Programming), while this is still relevant, SAP has now moved to RAP based development and a new concept called custom business configuration, both will be covered later in context of data maintenance.

Why we didn’t choose RAP or Custom business configuration for this use case.
  1. Custom business configuration ( Business configuration maintenance object ) – This is available from S4 On-Prem 2022 onwards and the Fiori app for CUBCO is available after 2023 onwards.
  2. RESTful ABAP Programming – SAP has provided RAP Generator which can generate all the artefacts based on a table right from views, behavior definition , service binding , generation to Fiori app however this is also not available in On-Prem 2021, the other workaround could be to build all these artefacts manually and generate Fiori app which was going to take more development time, hence it was avoided.

Since we cannot go with above 2 options, the only 2 options left are SM30 and Custom Business object, as we want to move towards Fiori first approach, Custom business object was chosen as the Go to approach. Let us deep dive in this with the help of use- case and practical tips

What is Custom Business Object –

With the Custom Business Objects Fiori app, you can create and manage custom business objects. A custom business object is a hierarchical set of database tables with an API for creation, retrieval, update and deletion of data.

  • In The Fiori App ‘Custom Business Object’, a new BO has been defined and maintained as below.
  • User can choose what options do they want as part of framework, e,g, Change document, system admin date (last change at, created at etc are added by default).
  • User interface is disabled in this since it is only possible to enable if Embedded gateway is used which is not the case here.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

You are free to choose what kind of operations, out of CUD, should be supported in the BO out of box.

This is where all the fields are defined for BO.

Final Output –

Until this point, no coding has been done except for few changes in CDS Metadata for Fiori UI related cosmetic changes, all the operation are handled by framework out of box.

An additional button ‘Mass upload’ was added in metadata extension which is using intent-based navigation to navigate to another GUI application for mass upload of the entries.

 

Few Tips -
  1. Custom Table (Type Application) is auto generated in this case with Key field as UUID.
  2. Data entries maintained in one system cannot be transported to other system and must be maintained in target system, which was also the requirement in our use case.
  3. Once business object is published and moved to production, Deletion is not allowed.

How does the future look like for the same activity (Table Maintenance)-

As discussed above, there are 2 other ways to achieve this with minimal development efforts in new S4 HANA releases.

  1. Custom Business Configuration

    This is recommended approach going forward where a business configuration maintenance object serves as primary entry point for maintenance.
  • We have the option to use the Generate ABAP Repository Objects Wizard for Business configuration maintenance object to generate all required development objects based on a customizing table
  • Based on the Business configuration maintenance object, the custom business configurations app renders a Fiori element list report for the entities exposed by the service binding to maintain the configuration entries

Image courtesy - SAP

In short, Custom business configuration (Fiori app) is an umbrella under which all maintenance objects will be listed and serves as one stop shop while maintenance objects are the actual ABAP artefact which contains all the definition related to Object maintenance.

  • Different options like SM30 are available by default such Add copy action out of box.
  • Add Data Consistency Check for fields with fixed domain values or foreign key screen check.

All of the below objects are created by default including CDS view, service definition, service binding, business object maintenance , transport definition, implementation classes etc.

Few Practical Tips –
  • All tables must have a client key field and delivery class C
  • Have a timestamp field with data element ABP_LASTCHANGE_TSTMPL
  • To enable the "No Transport" option in the ADT wizard, implement SAP Note  https://me.sap.com/notes/3579012.
  • With few tweaks, it is possible to maintain data directly in production system instead of transporting. More details in this blog

As of version SAP S/4HANA release 2022, customers can use the generator for Business Configuration objects. The Custom Business Configurations SAP Fiori app is not yet available; app has been made available in release 2023.

 

2. RAP Generator 

Second approach to achieve this is using same generation wizard from context menu of table.

How is Custom business configuration different than plain RAP generator?
  • Custom business configuration is a framework which is also built on RAP artefacts, but it has other framework related functionalities (e.g change log for auditing) in comparison to plain RAP application.
  • Fiori for CBC can be accessed through generic custom business configuration app serving as single source of entry whereas RAP application should be exposed as standalone app.
  • Custom business configuration app is built only around customizing tables whereas RAP generator can be built around any customizing and application tables both.
  • CBC provides in built functionality to capture entries into transport request, but RAP generator requires explicit changes to incorporate transport feature.
How is Custom business configuration different than custom business object?
  • Custom business configuration is built on RAP framework (SAP recommended) whereas custom business objects is built on BOPF framework.
  • Custom business configuration has transport feature for data entries whereas custom business object does not any way to transport entries from one system to other system.
  • Custom business configuration is bottom-up approach where custom tables are defined first, and rest of the artifacts are generated around that whereas custom business object works on top-down approach where business object is created first then custom table is generated around BO.
  • Custom business configuration supports only OData V4 where CBO supports OData V2.
  • Custom business configuration app is built only around customizing tables whereas custom business object is built around application tables.
  • Once CBO has moved to production, it cannot be deleted.
  • In both the case, Metadata can be enhanced for any Fiori related UI changes, also additional validation, actions are supported in both.

Additional reading-

  • https://help.sap.com/docs/ABAP_PLATFORM_NEW/b5670aaaa2364a29935f40b16499972d/047e01c3bcdd4303a60b61364bd5b31d.html?locale=en-US&version=202310.002
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/custom-business-configuration/ba-p/13647767
